title: Building High-Performance Engineering Teams
author: Victor Gutierrez
excerpt: How to transform underperforming teams into organizational references through culture, process, and technical excellence.
content:
The Challenge

When I joined the team at Leroy Merlin, we were known as the "major offender" - a team that consistently delivered late, had quality issues, and was avoided by other departments. The transformation that followed teaches us valuable lessons about leadership, culture, and technical excellence.

The Strategy

The transformation wasn't about individual heroics; it was about systematic change across three key areas:

1. Culture and Ownership: We established a culture where every team member felt ownership of the codebase and the business outcomes. This meant understanding not just the "how" but the "why" behind every feature.

2. Process and Standards: We implemented rigorous code review standards and established traceability between tickets and code development. This wasn't about bureaucracy - it was about creating predictable, quality outcomes.

3. Technical Excellence: We focused on reducing technical debt, improving testing coverage, and establishing proper deployment processes using Semantic Versioning methodology.

The Results

The transformation was measurable: 70% increase in Deployment Frequency, 74% reduction in Change Failure Rate, and 64% reduction in production incidents. More importantly, we became the team that other departments wanted to work with.

The key insight? High-performance teams aren't built on individual talent alone - they're built on systems, culture, and shared commitment to excellence.
